## GSEA Round 1 {#als2016-1}

**Last updated:** `r Sys.Date()`

**Code version:** `r system("git log -1 --format='%H'", intern = TRUE)`

### Fit the null model

I used the grids `theta0=(-6:0.25:-3)'` and `h=(0.3:0.1:0.6)'` when fitting the null model. I estimated the (unnormalized) log importance weights ("pseudo-likelihoods") for all 68 sets of `(h,theta0)` under null. 

```{r,echo=FALSE}
knitr::include_graphics("images/als2016_null_round1.png", dpi=NA)
```

After normalizing the log "pseudo-likelihoods" (`logw.step*`) to posterior probabilities (`posp.step*`), we can see that almost 99.99% posterior mass is concentrated on the settings `h=[0.3 0.4 0.5 0.6]` and `theta0 = (-6:0.25:-5)'`.
```{r, include=FALSE}
null.path <- "~/Dropbox/rss/Data/als_2016/pathway/als2016_null_201604.mat"
null.df <- null.mat2df(null.path)
```

```{r, echo=FALSE}
source("src/null_dt.R")
null.dt
```

```{r}
theta0.index <- null.df$theta0 %in% seq(-6,-5.,by=0.25) 
sum(null.df$posp.step2[theta0.index]) 
```

### Fit the enrichment model

To perform GSEA, I use a smaller grid that includes `h=[0.3 0.4 0.5 0.6]` and `theta0 = (-6:0.25:-5)'`, since the null analysis suggests that almost 99.99% posterior mass is placed on thses settings. For the log-fold enrichment parameter, I use the grid `theta=(0:(6/10):6)'`. The following table lists the GSEA results. 
```{r, include=FALSE}
gsea.path <- "~/Dropbox/rss/Data/als_2016/pathway/als2016_pathway_201604.mat"
gsea.df <- gsea.mat2df(gsea.path) 
```

```{r, echo=FALSE}
source("src/gsea_dt.R")
gsea.dt
```
